com.duprasville.guava.probably

Interface ProbabilisticFilter<E>

  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of instances that the ProbabilisticFilter accepts
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    BloomFilter, CuckooFilter

    public interface ProbabilisticFilter<E>
    A probabilistic filter offers an approximate containment test with one-sided error: if it claims that an object is contained in it, this might be in error, but if it claims that an object is not contained in it, then this is definitely true.

    The false positive probability (FPP) of a probabilistic filter is defined as the probability that contains(Object) will erroneously return true for an object that has not actually been added to the ProbabilisticFilter.

    Author:
    Brian Dupras

    • Method Detail

      • add

        @CheckReturnValue
boolean add(E e)
        Ensures that this filter contains the specified element.
        Returns:
        true if e was successfully added to the filter, false if this is definitely not the case. A return value of true ensures that contains(e) will also return true.

      • addAll

        @CheckReturnValue
boolean addAll(ProbabilisticFilter<E> f)
        Combines this filter with another compatible filter. The mutations happen to this instance. Callers must ensure this filter is appropriately sized to avoid saturating it or running out of space.
        Parameters:
        f - The filter to combine this filter with. f is not mutated.
        Returns:
        true if the operation was successful, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if isCompatible(f) == false

      • addAll

        @CheckReturnValue
boolean addAll(Collection<? extends E> c)
        Adds all of the elements in the specified collection to this filter. The behavior of this operation is undefined if the specified collection is modified while the operation is in progress.
        Returns:
        true if all elements of the collection were successfully added, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        ClassCastException - if the class of an element of the specified collection prevents it from being added to this collection
        NullPointerException - if the specified collection contains a null element and this filter does not permit null elements, or if the specified collection is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if some property of an element of the specified collection prevents it from being added to this filter
        IllegalStateException - if not all the elements can be added at this time due to insertion restrictions

      • contains

        boolean contains(E o)
        Returns true if this filter might contain the specified element.
        Parameters:
        o - element whose presence in this filter is to be tested
        Returns:
        true if this filter might contain the specified element, false if this is definitely not the case.

      • isEmpty

        boolean isEmpty()
        Returns true if this filter contains no elements.
        Returns:
        true if this collection contains no elements

      • size

        long size()
        Returns the number of elements in this filter.
        Returns:
        the number of elements in this filter.

      • currentFpp

        double currentFpp()
        Returns the current false positive probability of this filter.
        Returns:
        the probability that #contains(E) will erroneously return true for an element that has not actually been added to the filter.

      • isCompatible

        boolean isCompatible(ProbabilisticFilter<E> f)
        Returns true if f is compatible with this filter. f is considered compatible if this filter can use it in combinatoric operations (e.g. addAll(ProbabilisticFilter)).
        Parameters:
        f - The filter to check for compatibility.
        Returns:
        true if f is compatible with this filter.

      • capacity

        long capacity()
        Returns the number of elements this filter can represent at its desired @{code FPP}. This may not be a hard limit of the filter implementation. It is permissible for a filter to accept more elements than its expected capacity, though its FPP may suffer.
        Returns:
        the number of elements this filter can represent at its desired @{code FPP}.
        See Also:
        fpp(), currentFpp()

      • fpp

        double fpp()
        Returns the intended limit of this filter. This may not be a hard limit of the filter implementation. It is permissible for a filter's FPP to degrade (e.g. via saturation) beyond its intended limit.
        Returns:
        the intended limit of this filter.
